page.name: Literacy and Learning Differences
page.content:
Regardless of whether these issues have been officially diagnosed or not, many of the adult education (AE) learners in your classes are likely to experience learning or attention issues. It is important to take this into consideration as you design learning experiences for the adults in your class. Before designing any lesson or literacy task, remind yourself that: 

  • Adult learners will be prone to self-doubt and uncertainty about their ability to succeed or ever improve literacy skills.
  • Between 30% and 70% of those who have a disability that affects reading will also have a disability that affects their ability to perform math processes (Patterson, 2020). 
  • Many will lack the confidence to alert you to their reading comprehension, and writing challenges, or to ask for accommodations that would help them succeed. 
  • Adults with learning differences want to learn, but they will most likely have a history of uncompleted or negative learning experiences.  

Pro Tip: Get to know your adult learners’ backgrounds.
